title: On the Persistence of Groove: Structural Fog and Jouissance in a 'Split Open and Melt' Jam
Analytical Traditions and Game Music: Super Mario Galaxy as Case Study
Transcribing Musical Worlds, or, Is L.A. Noire a Music Game?
Barriers to Listening in World of Warcraft
A Sheep in Wolf's Corset: Timbral and Vocal Signifiers in The Rocky Horror Picture Show and Glee
Chaos in the Cosmos: The Play of Contradictions in the Music of Katamari Damacy

name: "Split Open and Melt" jam (Bomb Factory, Dallas)
Groove
description: Feel-based rhythmic patterning that invites bodily entrainment and movement.

name: Structural fog
description: Moments of maximal textural and rhythmic density in a groove that cloud perceivable structure.

name: Jouissance
description: Intense, often overwhelming pleasure that mixes delight and discomfort.

name: Participatory discrepancies
description: Microtiming deviations among performers that contribute to groove and feel.

name: Metric dissonance
description: Conflicts between layers of rhythmic grouping or accent that create metrical tension.

name: Grouping dissonance
description: A type of metric dissonance arising from incompatible grouping structures.

name: Barriers to listening
description: Game design features that prevent or complicate players' access to particular music.

name: Synchronic barrier
description: Barriers tied to a player's situation at a single moment in the game's lifecycle.

name: Diachronic barrier
description: Barriers that arise or change over the historical lifespan of a game.

name: Game world as score
description: The idea that spatial and ludic game structures function like a musical score to be performed.

name: Music game
description: Games whose core mechanics are organized around performing or interacting with music.

name: Ludic primacy
description: The assumption that gameplay has ontological priority over music or audiovisual elements.

name: Musical supplementarity
description: The assumption that music merely decorates or supports pre-existing gameplay and narrative.

name: Transformational analysis
description: Analytical approach that models music as networks of transformations between states.

name: Neo-Riemannian theory
description: Transformational theory focusing on parsimonious moves between triads.

name: Schenkerian analysis
description: Reductive method that relates surface events to deep background structures.

name: Tonnetz
description: Lattice diagram representing harmonic relations among triads and pitch classes.

name: Contradictory sound-image relation
description: Tension between what music seems to imply and what visuals or narrative present.

name: Timbral signifiers of gender
description: Associations between vocal/instrumental timbre and gendered identities.

name: Masculine agency
description: The way musical roles and vocal writing can privilege male control and subjectivity.

name: Ludomusicology
description: Scholarly study of music in and around games and play.
